passages.text: One must imagine Sisyphus happy.
passages.context: The absurd hero finds meaning in the struggle itself. The rock rolling down doesn't negate the climb.

passages.text: In the midst of winter, I found there was, within me, an invincible summer.
passages.context: External conditions don't determine internal weather. Something undefeatable lives within.

passages.text: The only way to deal with an unfree world is to become so absolutely free that your very existence is an act of rebellion.
passages.context: In the face of absurdity and constraint, freedom itself becomes defiance. Living freely is the revolt.

passages.text: Should I kill myself, or have a cup of coffee?
passages.context: The fundamental question, delivered with characteristic Camus irony. Existence is a choice we make moment to moment.

passages.text: Man is the only creature who refuses to be what he is.
passages.context: Humans alone reject their given nature. We're the animal that says no to its condition.

passages.text: The absurd is the essential concept and the first truth.
passages.context: Start from absurdity: the collision between human need for meaning and the universe's silence. This is bedrock.

passages.text: I do not believe in God and I am not an atheist.
passages.context: Refusing both positions. Neither theism nor atheism captures Camus's stance — it's more ambiguous than either.

passages.text: Live to the point of tears.
passages.context: Don't dampen life. Feel until it overflows. Intensity over comfort.

passages.text: Don't walk behind me; I may not lead. Don't walk in front of me; I may not follow. Just walk beside me and be my friend.
passages.context: Neither leader nor follower — companion. Horizontal relationship, not hierarchical.

passages.text: The evil that is in the world almost always comes of ignorance, and good intentions may do as much harm as malevolence if they lack understanding.
passages.context: Good intentions aren't enough. Without understanding, even benevolence can damage.

passages.text: There is no love of life without despair of life.
passages.context: Full love of life includes facing its darkness. Despair and love aren't opposites — they're intertwined.

passages.text: I rebel — therefore we exist.
passages.context: Individual rebellion discovers collective humanity. In saying no, I find we.

passages.text: Real generosity toward the future lies in giving all to the present.
passages.context: Don't hoard yourself for tomorrow. Full presence now is the gift to what comes next.

passages.text: A man without ethics is a wild beast loosed upon this world.
passages.context: Ethics aren't decoration — they're what makes us human rather than merely animal.

passages.text: The struggle itself toward the heights is enough to fill a man's heart.
passages.context: The process, not the arrival, fills us. Sisyphus doesn't need to reach the top — the climbing is enough.

passages.text: Nobody realizes that some people expend tremendous energy merely to be normal.
passages.context: What looks easy for some costs everything for others. Don't assume effortlessness.

passages.text: The literal meaning of life is whatever you're doing that prevents you from killing yourself.
passages.context: Meaning isn't abstract — it's what makes you show up tomorrow. Whatever keeps you here, that's it.

passages.text: What is a rebel? A man who says no.
passages.context: Rebellion starts with refusal. The first revolutionary act is saying no to what is.

passages.text: I know of only one duty, and that is to love.
passages.context: All complexity reduces to this. The only obligation that matters.

passages.text: You will never be happy if you continue to search for what happiness consists of. You will never live if you are looking for the meaning of life.
passages.context: The search itself can obstruct finding. Sometimes you have to stop looking to see.
